Award.AwardTitle: A Synthetic-Biology Approach to Study Scaling Properties of Self-Organized Patterns

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Using engineered gene circuits as a model system, the proposed work aims to examine the scaling properties of self-organized patterns. It focuses on a unique property, scale invariance, or maintenance of constant relative size of an organ with respect to the whole body during animal development or between individuals. The project represents a transformative application of synthetic biology to address unresolved, fundamental questions in biology. The proposed computational and experimental framework provides a well-defined context for exploring design principles that underlie generation of self-organized pattern formation as well as the emergent scaling properties. In addition to offering new biological insights, the proposed engineered systems can serve as the foundation for future engineering endeavors, such as fabrication of novel biomaterials. Furthermore, experimental techniques and computational infrastructure arising from the proposed work will be applicable for analyzing both natural and synthetic biological networks. Both computational and experimental systems and tools will be made available to the broad research community.

Equally important, the research in this project will provide opportunities for pre-college students, undergraduates, and graduate students with backgrounds in biology, engineering, mathematics, and physical sciences to become exposed to interdisciplinary research in bioengineering and synthetic biology. Modeling examples and experiments derived from the proposed research, along with other examples drawn from the literature, will be used to train these students. In addition, the course and curriculum development will facilitate dissemination of knowledge in Systems and Synthetic Biology both at and beyond Duke University. Finally, to support both short-term and long-term education goals, the proposed efforts include development of a textbook on systems and synthetic biology that targets upper-level undergraduate students and starting graduate students.

Technical description: The project aims to use a combination of mathematical modeling and experimental analysis of synthetic gene circuits to explore the fundamental mechanisms underlying scaling properties of self-organized patterns. Scale invariance refers to maintenance of constant relative size of an organ with respect to the whole body during animal development or between individuals. A number of mechanisms have been proposed to explain scale invariance in biological pattern formation. Regardless of their specific molecular interactions, however, the vast majority of these mechanisms require morphogen gradients as the spatial cue, which are either predefined or generated as part of the patterning process. In preliminary work, using Escherichia coli programmed by a synthetic gene circuit, the investigator has demonstrated the generation of perfect scale invariance of ring size versus colony size in robust, self-organized ring patterns of gene expression in the absence of an apparent morphogen gradient. This observation raises a fundamental, unresolved question: How does scale invariance occur in self-organized patterns in the absence of a spatial morphogen gradient? To address this question, the investigator proposes to develop and optimize an experimental platform to examine scaling properties of self-organized pattern formation in engineered bacteria. This platform couples inkjet printing technology and synthetic gene circuitry to explore the role of morphogen as a temporal cue in the pattern formation process, guided by mechanistically based mathematical models.

This award is funded jointly by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program in MCB and the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering Program in CBET.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A synthetic-biology approach to study scaling properties of self-organized patterns

Lingchong You, Duke University

Project Summary

Overview

The proposed work aims to use a combination of mathematical modeling and experimental analysis of synthetic gene circuits to explore the fundamental mechanisms underlying scaling properties of self-organized patterns. In addition, we will integrate research with education by providing a platform for under-represented students to carry out short-term or long-term research and by integrating aspects of the proposed research into classroom teaching.  Scale invariance refers to maintenance of constant relative size of an organ with respect to the whole-body during animal development or between individuals.  A number of mechanisms have been proposed to explain scale invariance in biological pattern formation. Regardless of their specific molecular interactions, however, the vast majority of these mechanisms require morphogen gradients as the spatial cue, which are either predefined or generated as part of the patterning process. In our preliminary work, using Escherichia coli programmed by a synthetic gene circuit, we have demonstrated the generation of perfect scale invariance of ring size vs. colony size in robust, self-organized ring patterns of gene expression in the absence of an apparent morphogen gradient. This observation raises a fundamental, unresolved question:  How does scale invariance occur in self-organized patterns in the absence of a spatial morphogen gradient? To address this question, the proposed research aimed to develop and optimize an experimental platform to examine scaling properties of self-organized pattern formation in engineered bacteria. This platform couples inkjet printing technology and synthetic gene circuitry to explore the role of morphogen as a temporal cue in the pattern formation process, guided by mechanistically based mathematical models.

 

Outcomes to address intellectual merits. 

During the proposed research, we were able to generate robust and predictable self-organized patterns in bacteria when the cells were initially engulfed in a soft agar droplet or printed on agar surface. During the process, we have investigated how to generate reproducible, controllable, and spatially standardized patterns in bacterial microcolonies, by modulating the experimental conditions as well as the circuit dynamics. As part of the research, we have developed new computational approaches accelerate model predictions and to provide new biological insights.

The key outcomes include:

1)     Demonstration of the predictable programming of self organized pattern formation using an engineered gene circuit and its variants. This circuit is one of the handful of gene circuits able to program self-organized pattern formation, in a predictable manner.

2)     Demonstration of a basic principle underlying the scale invariance in the generated self-organized patterns.

3)     Development of new experimental techniques to control pattern formation.

4)     Development of a machine-learning approach to accelerate prediction of self-organized pattern formation. In particular, we demonstrated that the use of an appropriately trained neural network accelerates predictions by up to 30,000 fold. This capability drastically accelerates our ability to examine the patterning capability of different circuits. The methodology is also generally applicable to other systems ? an aspect we are exploring in ongoing research.

5)     Development of a modeling framework to analyze a type of gene circuit dynamics in growing colonies. By relying on ordinary differential equations, the framework can facilitate the speed of numerical simulations and the development of novel mechanistic insights into the patterning dynamics.

Outcomes to address broader impact

      Throughout the proposed research, we actively engaged trainees at all career stages in research, including undergraduate students and graduate students. Leveraging local funding resources, we  initiated an research/outreach project (The Blue Devil Resistome Project) through the Bass Connections program at Duke, a unique program that aims to foster undergraduate research at Duke. In this one-year project, we recruited a dozen undergraduate students (8 were women) from different departments (Biomedical Engineering, Biology, Computer Science, and Chemistry). These students participated in a one-year project sampling resistant bacteria across the Duke campus. They isolated >600 environment samples, consisting of ~150 unique isolates based on subsequent whole genome sequencing. They carried out several phenotypic assays on these isolates, including antibiotic resistance and capability of horizontal gene transfer. During 2019, four of the initial participants continued follow-up research in the You lab, as part of their independent studies or dissertation research. Two of these students (Youlim Kim and Ammara Aqueel) recently graduated with distinction from the Department of Biology at Duke.
